questions.question_text: Which of the following ports are used for secure sessions? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Port 22 - Secure Shell (SSH)
Port 443 - Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS)
Good point to remember for Port 23 - Telnet, should always be avoided as it is unsecure/unencrypted

Selected Answer: AF
A and F

port 23 - telnet (remotely access to peripheral)
port 25 is SMTP (sending an email)
port 80 - HTTP (Hyper text)
port 110 - pop3 (receiving email)

choices.E: Research the problem based on symptoms.
choices.C: Reconnect the device to the network.
choices.B: Reboot the device to verify the fix.

discussion.content: running a virus scan is considered preventive maintenance and part of verifying full system functionality ( comptia answer)

How did the tech remove malware without running a virus scan? Another nonsense question from comptia. The tech would have already run a virus scan on this computer to discover and remove the malware that was stated in the question. I guess comptia is trying to imply that running a virus scan in the answer is the second time the virus scan is being run to confirm that the system is clean.

comments.content: he ran a virus scan and removed the malware, that was the fix. And to verify the fix he ran another virus scan
Reading peoples comments are the best.
You can remove malware without doing a virus scan. Research what malware is.

discussion.content: Comptia has 6 troubleshooting guides for resolving issues. The Technician connecting to the internet has performed step 4. The next two steps are to verify full functionality and document. The answer should be A and B.

A. Document findings, actions, and outcomes.
B. Reboot the device to verify the fix.

Here's the rationale for each choice:

A. Document findings, actions, and outcomes: Proper documentation is essential in troubleshooting. Documenting the findings, actions taken, and the resulting outcomes helps in maintaining a record of the troubleshooting process. This information can be useful for future reference and in sharing insights with colleagues.

B. Reboot the device to verify the fix: Rebooting the device after making changes or fixing an issue is a common step to ensure that the changes take effect. It helps confirm whether the problem is resolved and if the system functions properly after the applied fixes.

While the other options (C, D, E, and F) might be relevant in certain troubleshooting scenarios, they are not the immediate next steps after removing malware and verifying basic connectivity.
Ucertify has this question... its not AF.... its AB

Selected Answer: AF
I think the answer should be A,F
run anti virus
Why wouldn't you want to reboot the device before running a virus scan?

comments.content: It could trigger more actions within the malware/virus.

discussion.content: another bad written question... answer A is sure but B is a a possibile alternative to F. in fact running a virus scan is not "scheduling a virus scan" so it's not a preventive mesure.
I think the right answer is:B &F

The correct answer should be b, e, and f. I'm not liking these questions and answers either. Seems to me that CompTIA is deliberately being ambiguous and in some cases overly complicated so that people fail the test. See, if you don't buy one of their bundles and you fail a test, you have to pay full price to be retested, which is a rip off all day long. Especially when you have to pay more than a couple hundred dollars. I can't stand organizations that use people like that, and I'm surprised no one has filed a class action lawsuit against them for that BS.

If malware is found on a machine, and the tech is able to remove the malware by uninstalling it, a virus scan should still be run as well. 
Virus definitions should be updated first of course, (well they SHOULD be automatically updated) and the virus scan might detect if the malware has left any malicious payloads on the machine. 
Next, you should reboot the machine, which does two things: First, it allows the antivirus and any other changes needed to finish, and second, it will help to verify that the malware did not leave any "reinfection" system in place. If the computer reboots cleanly, and no re-infection occurs, you have the user verify everything is working as it should.(That's Professionalism)
and THEN you document your findings, actions and outcomes... 

B&F

"Documents findings, actions, and outcomes." should be preformed before removed malware.
I think answer is BF
wow! some of the answers given make no sense and go against what i have read in compTIOA A+ text books

Some well crafted viruses can automatically reinstall on the next boot. 
https://forums.tomsguide.com/threads/virus-surviving-reinstall-please-help.419441/

A user is unable to access websites and has reported connectivity issues with pop-ups on the screen. A technician removes malware, and then is able to ping the router and access the websites.
Which of the following NEXT steps should the technician perform in troubleshooting this issue? (Choose two.)

Always remember to choose the best option from those provided. That's KEY to getting these right, which is something Professor Messer always stresses. He's right. VR headset is designed to block out light, entirely. E-reader is supposed to be usable in light, but that doesn't supply the best answer to the question from the options available. That said, I chose e-reader, because I wanted it to be that. I ignored the correct choice, because I had a predisposition to the e-reader based on my studies.
Correct answer is E - Reader, Amazon kindle is a best example where VR is for entertainment purpose only and not related to a harsh lighting.

E-reader serves that exact purpose. To make it easier to read in direct sunlight.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is designed to function BEST in harsh lighting conditions?

discussion.content:
RJ-11 is commonly used for telephone lines and is the most correct answer.
RG-6 and RG-59 are coaxial cable standards.
RJ-45 is used to terminate Ethernet cables.

questions.question_text: Which of the following connector types is used to terminate household telephone cabling?
A shipping department is having problems with its thermal label printer. Two columns on the left are not appearing on all labels. Which of the following should a technician do FIRST?

discussion.content: Stuck labels could cause paper jams or printing issues, but this wouldn't specifically cause two columns to be missing from the labels consistently. Calibration would likely resolve the issue more directly.

The correct answer is C, because A thermal transfer printer uses a ribbon, sure. but the official comptia textbook says that the most common type of thermal printer you will have to support is a direct thermal printer, which are used for high volume barcode and label printing. The Comptia studyguide specifically focuses on how label printers can leave sticky residue behind, and need cleaning, and that you should know how to remove stuck labels from the printer.
The thing to look out for it the word FIRST they aren't looking for the most likely fix here they're looking for the path of least resistance. That's the best way I can explain the answer

Why is it that so many of CompTIA's questions require us to completely ignore some detail that they provide in the simulation, and assume some Other detail is the one that we have to answer to? - A thermal transfer printer uses a ribbon, sure. but the official comptia textbook says that the most common type of thermal printer you will have to support is a direct thermal printer, which are used for high volume barcode and label printing.

The Comptia studyguide specifically focuses on how label printers can leave sticky residue behind, and need cleaning, and that you should know how to remove stuck labels from the printer.
As always, you have to derive the BEST choice from the OPTIONS available. The only answer that made any sense with regard to the thermal printer was A.
I would go for the print head replacement. Thermal printers do not use ribbon (Dot-matrix are).

comments.content:
It depends if you are using a direct thermal printer or thermal transfer printer. Thermal transfer printers use ribbon made of wax or resin-based ink to melt onto the print media (a label or similar)

https://brothermobilesolutions.com/2019/10/09/direct-thermal-vs-thermal-transfer-which-print-technology-works-best/

The only reason I am going with A is that CompTIA wants to make sure the issue isn't from the users first.

discussion.content:
"label" is the keyword.
https://www.directindustry.com/prod/novexx-solutions-gmbh/product-179020-1775940.html
thermal printer uses thermal paper to print stuff like receipts...
A label printer is used to print using labels.
I think A is right answer, we do that in our company too.
Should state it is a thermal transfer printer and not a direct thermal printer. Thermal transfer printers use a ribbon where as direct thermal printers use thermal paper.
